markdownRemark.html:
Photo by Yannik Wenk on Unsplash

This article is part of a series on migrating to Elastic Beanstalk from a 12-factor application platform. It also introduces our elastic_beans CLI, a replacement for the built-in AWS eb CLI. For an explanation of why we chose Elastic Beanstalk, and why we chose to write a replacement CLI, see the first article in the series.

  1. Migrating to Elastic Beanstalk
  2. End-to-End Encryption and Private Networking
  3. Migrating Background Jobs to SQS
  4. Periodic Tasks

Security is our priority, and ensuring we protect our patients' data was a major focus for this migration. We must protect network traffic, data stored on our servers, and data stored on our clients. Client access to data is outside the scope of this series, but in this document I will discuss network architecture and end-to-end encryption on Elastic Beanstalk.

Network architecture

Running on a public platform meant we couldn't take much advantage of firewalls. Instead we had to rely only on authentication to protect access to our data. Migrating to Elastic Beanstalk afforded us the opportunity to rethink our application's network architecture.

Using a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC), we can segregate our instances by their traffic patterns. We create three subnets in each availability zone we want to use: one for application instances, one for load balancers, and one for a bastion server. Each subnet has a route table and a security group that is specific to its function.

The application route table uses a NAT gateway to allow egress traffic to reach the outside internet. The application security group allows only HTTP and HTTPS ingress traffic (ports 80 and 443), and only from the load balancer security group. In turn the load balancer security group allows only HTTP and HTTPS ingress traffic, but from anywhere. The route table for the load balancer subnet uses an internet gateway to route traffic, because the subnet is only for publicly-accessible nodes.

The bastion subnet shares a route table with the load balancer subnet because it is also intended for public access. However its security group only allows SSH ingress traffic (port 22). We have one more security group to allow SSH ingress traffic from the bastion server to the application instances.

These resources must all exist separately in each of development, staging, and production environments. Using [CloudFormation][] we can write a template encoding these resources and relationships and deploy it in each environment. The elastic_beans wiki has an example that includes everything necessary.

Integration with Elastic Beanstalk

Elastic Beanstalk supports a VPC public/private network architecture like this one, but requires some configuration before creating instances. elastic_beans will configure this automatically using the configure command, given the appropriate CloudFormation stack. Using CloudFormation is a best practice that also minimizes the number of arguments we must pass to elastic_beans.

beans configure -a myapp -n networking-development

This command assumes we have already created our Elastic Beanstalk application and named it myapp. elastic_beans fetches the appropriate details from the Outputs configured in the template and sets them in configuration templates, also known as saved configurations. Any applications we create using elastic_beans will use the correct configuration template and be created in our desired network layout.

We can re-use this networking stack for more applications if we are comfortable with them sharing a network. This is useful for development environments that will not contain sensitive data.

beans configure -a another-app -n networking-development

Bastion server

The bastion server serves as an SSH proxy if we need shell access to our application instances. During the configure command, elastic_beans found our security group allowing access from the bastion server to our application instances and added it to the Elastic Beanstalk configuration. Now, if we have the private key and public IP address for the bastion server and the private IP address of the application instance we want to access, we can proxy through the bastion using ssh. elastic_beans also automates this for us:

beans ssh webserver -a myapp \
  -i $KEYPAIR \
  --bastion-host $BASTION_IP --bastion-username $USER \
  --bastion-identity-file $PRIVATE_KEY

That said, shell access is rarely needed. Debugging is more effective using metrics and log aggregation and searching and monitoring in those places. Instead of running commands in an SSH session, commands are run using beans exec:

beans exec rake db:migrate -a myapp

Due to how powerful a local user can be, adequate protection of the bastion server is essential. Beyond attack and vulnerability mitigation, normal access must be controlled. Auditing access, protecting it behind multi-factor authentication, and good policy and access control are examples of ways to do this.

End-to-end encryption

Once our network is appropriately constructed, we can focus on protecting data in transit and at rest on our servers.

Data in transit

There are a couple different places we must encrypt data in transit.

  • Clients send data to the ELB that Elastic Beanstalk creates
  • The ELB sends data to application instances

I will discuss both of these. There are a lot of other ways data is transmitted that I will not discuss, because the solutions are less reusable:

  • SSH clients can access data by virtue of being on a host
  • Data is sent to various services, e.g. stored in RDBMS or key-value store, indexed by a search service, integrated with third parties
  • Logs are sent to a log aggregation service

Protecting each of these data transmissions is outside the scope of this article. The solutions are specific to the service and methods in use. The basic guiding principle is: all network access should be encrypted and trusted.

Clients send data to the ELB

To protect data in transit from a client to our load balancer, we use HTTPS. Elastic Load Balancers are configured with a listener for HTTPS traffic coupled with an IAM server certificate. Elastic Beanstalk can be configured to set up its load balancers for HTTPS traffic. elastic_beans automates this configuration for us! Given that we have our own domain and a valid certificate for that domain, we can upload it along with its private key and the certificate chain for our certificate authority (CA). Once uploaded, we have an ARN representing that certificate within IAM.

$ aws iam upload-server-certificate ...
{
    "ServerCertificateMetadata": {
        "ServerCertificateId": "...",
        "ServerCertificateName": "...",
        "Expiration": "...",
        "Path": "/",
        "Arn": "arn:aws:iam::123456789012:server-certificate/elastic-beanstalk-x509",
        "UploadDate": "..."
    }
}

We pass that ARN to elastic_beans so it can configure all of the Elastic Beanstalk option settings automatically for us. ðŸŽ‰

beans configure -a myapp -n networking-development \
  -s arn:aws:iam::123456789012:server-certificate/elastic-beanstalk-x509

ELB sends data to application instances

With a server certificate configured on our ELB, it will decrypt traffic at that point. This means data is passed around within our VPC unencrypted, which is unacceptable. Unencrypted data over a network connection, even within a VPC, could be leaked, intentionally or unintentionally. We can encrypt data that is passed from the ELB to our application instances:

  • configure nginx to listen for HTTPS traffic with an SSL certificate and private key
  • configure a backend policy on the ELB with the public key for that certificate

Since this certificate is only used internally, we can self-sign a certificate, or use a valid certificate. Security groups were defined in our CloudFormation stack following the guidelines from the "Network Architecture" section discussed earlier. elastic_beans will use those and set up our ELB listeners correctly. A future version of elastic_beans could generate an internal certificate and set up an HTTPS server on nginx automatically; for now, our application must configure nginx and give elastic_beans the public key for the load balancer.

We set up anÂ .ebextensions configuration for nginx following the directions from the first bullet point above. It creates files with our certificate and private key, and adds nginx configuration for an HTTPS server using the certificate and private key. We can find our public key using openssl:

$ openssl x509 -in ./cert.crt -noout -pubkey
-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----
SOMEPUBLICKEYCONTENTS
-----END PUBLIC KEY-----

Then we can pass the contents of the public key to beans configure to set up the ELB backend policy:

beans configure -a myapp -n networking-development \
  -p 'SOMEPUBLICKEYCONTENTS'

Data at rest

The data from a request generally does not reach the disk, but it is logged and our log files are stored on disk. We can encrypt the AMIs provided by Elastic Beanstalk and configure our application to use the encrypted versions. First we must create our own copy of the image, then we can encrypt it using a key from Amazon KMS, and clean up the unencrypted copy. We've automated this in our continuous integration system so that every new Elastic Beanstalk image is copied and encrypted.

Once we have an encrypted image, we use elastic_beans to configure our servers to use it instead of the default. Existing instances will be re-created, and any new environments or instances will be created using this image.

beans configure -a myapp -n networking-development \
  -i $AMI_ID

Configuring with elastic_beans

All together, the options discussed in this article are used by beans configure to set up an Elastic Beanstalk application for end-to-end encryption. This saves us a lot of manual work on every application we set up!

beans configure -a $APP_NAME \
  -n $NETWORKING_CLOUDFORMATION_STACK \
  -i $AMI_ID \
  -s $SERVER_CERTIFICATE_ARN \
  -p $PUBLIC_KEY

Elastic Beanstalk Migration

Overall the migration process has been fairly straightforward. elastic_beans has helped the Core Infrastructure group spare the rest of the team from most of these difficulties. We are excited to be using a more secure, compliant, and scalable hosting platform!

In future articles in this series, I will cover some of the issues we have overcome and how elastic_beans helps us solve them.

  1. Migrating to Elastic Beanstalk
  2. End-to-End Encryption and Private Networking
  3. Migrating Background Jobs to SQS
  4. Periodic Tasks

post.title: Elastic Beanstalk: End-to-End Encryption and Private Networking
